( A )

( B )

A j

( X )

Math.text: nu * ((union _ (j = 1)) ^ infinity)@(A _ j) less= ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ infinity)@(nu * A _ j)

para.p:
We say that a subset
A
of
X
is
ν
-measurable if

Math.text: formulae@(nu * E = nu * (E intersection A) + nu * (E intersection A ^ c), E element-of P * X)

para.p:
Here, instead of taking a
σ
-algebra as given and then defining a measure on this
σ
-algebra (namely, on the measurable sets), we take an outer measure as given and then define measurable sets using this outer measure. Carathéodory’s theorem 1 1 footnote 1 Gerald B. Folland, Real Analysis, second ed., p. 29, Theorem 1.11. states that the collection
M
of
ν
-measurable sets is a
σ
-algebra and that the restriction of
ν
to
M
is a complete measure.

Suppose that
( X , ρ )
is a metric space. An outer measure
ν
on
X
is said to be a metric outer measure if

Math.text: rho * open-interval@(A, B) = infimum@(conditional-set@(rho * open-interval@(a, b), formulae@(a element-of A, b element-of B))) > 0

para.p: implies that

Math.text: nu * (A union B) = nu * A + nu * B

para.p:
We prove that the Borel sets are
ν
-measurable. 2 2 footnote 2 Gerald B. Folland, Real Analysis, second ed., p. 349, Proposition 11.16. That is, we prove that the Borel
σ
-algebra is contained in the
σ
-algebra of
ν
-measurable sets.

If
ν
is a metric outer measure on a metric space
( X , ρ )
, then every Borel set is
ν
-measurable.

Because
ν
is an outer measure, by Carathéodory’s theorem the collection
M
of
ν
-measurable sets is a
σ
-algebra, and hence to prove that
M
contains the Borel
σ
-algebra it suffices to prove that
M
contains all the closed sets. Let
F
be a closed set in
X
, and let
E
be a subset of
X
. Because
ν
is an outer measure,

Math.text: nu * E = nu * ((E intersection F) union (E intersection F ^ c)) less= nu * (E intersection F) + nu * (E intersection F ^ c)

para.p:
In the case
=
⁢ ν
( E )
∞
, certainly
≥
⁢ ν
( E )
+
⁢ ν
(

)

(

F c
)

<

n

para.p:

We call the metric outer measure
:
H p
→
⁢ P
( X )
[ 0 , ∞ ]

p

H p
to the Borel
σ
-algebra
B X
of a metric space is a meausure. We call this restriction the
p
-dimensional Hausdorff measure, and denote it also by
H p
.

R n

is invariant under translations.

Before speaking about Hausdorff measure on
R n
, we remind ourselves of some material about Radon measures and Haar measures. Let
X
be a locally compact Hausdorff space. A Borel measure
μ
on
X
is said to be a Radon measure if (i) it is finite on each compact set, (ii) for any Borel set
E
,

Math.text: mu * E = infimum@(conditional-set@(mu * U, [U open and ⊂EU]))

para.p:
and (iii) for any open set
E
,

Math.text: mu * E = supremum@(conditional-set@(mu * K, [K compact and ⊂KE]))

para.p:
It is a fact that if
X
is a locally compact Hausdorff space in which every open set is
σ
-compact, then every Borel measure on
X
that is finite on compact sets is a Radon measure. 6 6 footnote 6 Gerald B. Folland, Real Analysis, second ed., p. 217, Theorem 7.8.

Suppose that
G
is a locally compact group. A Borel measure
μ
on
G
is said to be left-invariant if for all
∈ x G
and
∈ E
B G
,

Math.text: mu * x * E = mu * E

para.p:
A left Haar measure on
G
is a nonzero left-invariant Radon measure on
G
. It is a fact that if
μ
and
ν
are left Haar measures on
G
then there is some
> c 0
such that
= μ
⁢ c ν
. 7 7 footnote 7 Gerald B. Folland, Real Analysis, second ed., p. 344, Theorem 11.9.

Let
m n
denote Lebesgue measure on
R n
.

If
E
is a Borel set in
R n
, then

Math.text: H _ n * E >= 2 ^ n * m _ n * E

Let
> ϵ 0
and let
{
E j

E
and such that

Math.text: sum@((diam * E _ j) ^ n) less= H _ n * E + epsilon

The isodiametric inequality (which one proves using the Brunn-Minkowski inequality) states that if
A
is a Borel set in
R n
, then

Math.text: m _ n * A less= ((diam * A) / 2) ^ n

para.p: Using this gives

Math.text: sum@(2 ^ n * m _ n * E _ j) less= H _ n * E + epsilon

para.p:
But because the sets
E j
cover
E
we have
⁢
m n
( E )
≤
⁢
m n
(
⋃
E j
)
≤
∑
⁢
m n
(
E j
)
, so we get

Math.text: m _ n * E less= (H _ n * E + epsilon) / 2 ^ n

para.p:
This expression does not involve the sets
E j
(which depend on
ϵ
), and since this expression is true for any
> ϵ 0
, taking
→ ϵ 0
yields

Math.text: m _ n * E less= (H _ n * E) / 2 ^ n

para.p: Let

Math.text: Q = conditional-set@(x element-of R ^ n, formulae@(absolute-value@(x _ 1) less= list@(1 / 2, ldots), absolute-value@(x _ n) less= 1 / 2))

para.p:
For any
≥ m 1
, the cube
Q
can be covered by
m n
cubes
q 1
, … ,
q
m n
of side length
1 m
. Let
0 < δ < 1
and let
> m
1 δ
. The distance from the center of
q j
to one of the vertices of
q j
is

Math.text: r = square-root@((1 / (2 * m)) ^ 2 + cdots + (1 / (2 * m)) ^ 2) = square-root@(n) / (2 * m)

para.p:
Inscribe
q j
in a closed ball
b j
with the same center as
q j
and radius
r
. These balls cover
Q
. Hence

Math.text: H _ (list@(p, delta)) * Q less= ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ m ^ n)@((diam * b _ j) ^ n) = ((sum _ (j = 1)) ^ m ^ n)@((2 * r) ^ n) = (2 * r) ^ n cdot m ^ n = n ^ (n / 2)

para.p:
Taking
→ δ 0
gives
⁢
H p
( Q )
≤
n
/ n 2

.
On the other hand, by Lemma ,

There is some constant
>
c n
0
such that

Math.text: H _ n = c _ n * m _ n

para.p:
R n
is a locally compact Hausdorff space in which every open set in
R n
is
σ
-compact. Therefore, to show that
H n
is a Radon measure it suffices to show that
H n
is finite on every compact set. If
K
is a compact subset of
R n
, there is some
> r 0
such that
⊂ K
⁢ r Q
. By Lemma and Lemma we get
<
⁢
H n
(
⁢ r Q
)
∞
, so
<
⁢
H n
( K )
∞
. Therefore
H n
is a Radon measure.

Because
>
⁢
H n

0
,
H n
is not the zero measure. Any translation is an isometric isomorphism
→
R n
R n
, so
H n
is invariant under translations. Thus
H n
is a left Haar measure on
R n
. But Lebesgue measure
m n
is also a left Haar measure on
R n
, so there is some
>
c n
0
such that

Math.text: H _ n = c _ n * m _ n

para.p: proving the claim. ∎
